content: How can I help you today?

I've been having trouble sleeping lately. My mind feels like it's racing all the time, especially at night. It all started because of stress at work, and it's just been getting worse. I don’t know what to do.
It sounds like your sleepless nights have become deeply tied to the stress from work, and that must feel exhausting and overwhelming. What’s been weighing on your mind about your work situation?

I’m just worried that things at work aren’t going well, and with how the economy is right now, I keep thinking I might be one of the first to get let go if layoffs happen. I feel like I can’t turn my brain off at night—just racing thoughts about bills, my family, what I’d do if it happens. It’s hard to feel in control of anything.

Worrying about layoffs and financial stability sounds incredibly stressful, especially when you're trying to care for your family and keep everything in balance. It seems like not being able to turn off those racing thoughts at night is taking a real toll on you. How have you been handling these thoughts and feelings so far?

I’ve tried to distract myself—usually with my phone—but it just ends up making things worse. I know it’s counterproductive, but it’s hard to stop. Other than that, I mostly keep these worries to myself, but they’re always there in the back of my mind.

It sounds like you’re really trying to cope in the moment, but those distractions haven’t given you the relief you hoped for. Keeping these worries to yourself must feel isolating at times, especially when they’re so persistent. Have there been any moments where you’ve felt even a small sense of ease or calm?

I guess the only small moments of calm I get are when I’m playing with my kids. For a little while, I can focus on just being with them, but as soon as I stop, all the worries come rushing back. It’s hard to stay in that good headspace for long.

Spending time with your kids seems to give you a brief sense of peace and connection, even in the midst of everything you’re dealing with. It sounds like those moments are really meaningful to you. What do you think draws you to that space of calm when you’re with them?

I think it’s just that they’re so full of energy and life, and they don’t have any of the worries I do. For those moments, I can step out of my head and just focus on them. But I always know the stress will creep back in as soon as I stop. It’s like I can never fully escape it.

Being with your kids sounds like a special escape, where their energy and innocence pull you away from the weight of your worries, even if just for a while. Yet, the stress always seems to find a way back, keeping you stuck in a cycle. What do you think might help shift things—even a little—to feel more in control of your thoughts and nighttime rest?

I’m really not sure. I’ve thought about trying to put my phone away or doing something like meditation, but honestly, I don’t know if that would actually help. It just feels overwhelming to figure out where to start.

Starting something new can feel daunting, especially when things already feel overwhelming. Thinking about putting your phone away or trying meditation shows that you’ve considered ways to create some space in your mind. What do you feel might make it easier or more manageable to try something that could help with the stress and sleep struggles?

Maybe starting small would help. Like setting my phone down for just ten minutes before bed and seeing how that goes. I guess if it feels doable, I’d be more likely to stick with it, but it’s hard to know if it’ll make a real difference.

Starting small, like setting your phone down for ten minutes, sounds like a thoughtful way to test out a change without overwhelming yourself. Even small shifts can be meaningful over time. How do you feel about giving that a try and seeing where it leads?

I could try it, I guess. Ten minutes doesn’t feel too overwhelming, and maybe it’s worth seeing if it helps at all. I’m still not sure it’ll make a difference, but I can start there and see what happens.

That sounds like a realistic and thoughtful first step! It’s great that you’re open to giving it a try, even with some uncertainty—it can take time to see how small changes add up. Is there anything else you’d like to explore or talk about before moving forward with this idea?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
